ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to consider various competing interests when making business decisions. Shareholder theory and stakeholder theory were big components.
About business ethics theories and ways of thinking related problems.
I learned about the diverse approaches to business ethics, as well as the connections of these approaches to business law.

I learned about shareholder, stakeholder, and virtue theories. And the second half of the semester is about application of the theories into real-life situations such as ethical issues in finance and pharmaceuticals.

A fundamental understanding of different approaches to business ethics, including shareholder theory, stakeholder theory, and virtue theory. I also learned how to read court cases in a more in depth manner.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A lot of readings for the course, which is both helpful and exhausting.
Kind professor, great topics, manageable workload, fun discussions. I really liked this class.

Strengths: Prof. Landis asked really intellectual and important questions in class to drive class discussions.
What could be improved: I think it might be better if there is a bit more lecturing content. The seminar is almost purely class discussions.
The content is interesting and the professor allows students to guide discussion towards topic areas that interest them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, as the grading is fairly easy and occasionally discussions get quite interesting. However, seminar can get very boring.
Yes, helpful to reading all the famous business ethics readings.
Definitely! The subjects we covered were fun, the workload is really manageable, and Professor Landis is kind and even funny at times
Yes if you are interested in business ethics and reading law cases.
If the readings look interesting to you, then I definitely recommend it. Professor Landis is a kind and reasonable professor, and the class discussions are very student-driven.
Tentatively yes. The content is interesting but the class itself could be more engaging.
